Dear Sirs— RE: Fort Frances Indian Residential School.

I am in receipt of your letter of the 24th ult., advising what action your department has taken concerning the question of sewage disposal for the above institution.

The report prepared by your Acting District Chief Engineer stating that unrestricted contamination of Rainy Lake is permitted and that immense quantities of raw sewage are discharged in Rainy River hardly has a bearing in this connection. As far as that area there is a great deal of sewage discharged untreated all over this province and in every other country. The problem with which we are concerned is that the location of this discharge must be such that it will not interfere with water supplies, bathing beaches etc. We asked your department to take action concerning this school because of its proximity to the Fort Frances water intake and to the bathing beach and park in that municipality. The fact that other places not interfering with water intakes discharge their sewage untreated hardly seems a justification for this being done at the school. I might point out also that an effort is being made to determine the extent of pollution in the Rainy River and the methods of disposal which will be required for these wastes. Naturally we are quite disappointed that your department has not seen fit to take action towards the installation of a proper disposal plant for this school, and I would again urge that action be taken at the first opportunity.

Yours very truly,

A. E. Avery
Director, Sanitary Engineering Division.

Director, Branch Laboratory
BACTERIOLOGICAL EXAMINATION

(a) When one sample is being submitted, use the sample bottle and mailing case provided for the same. Kindly note the directions for taking the sample on the reverse side of the data sheet. A bacteriological examination should be carried out in five days.

(b) When more than one sample is being submitted, kindly use the sample bottle provided for each sample.

(c) Should a bacterial plate count be desired, the samples should be packed in ice. A card or label, bearing the name of the water supplier, should be attached to each sample bottle.

CHEMICAL EXAMINATION

Sanitary and mineral analyses of water supplies are carried out for microbiological, and in special instances, where necessary, for chemical analysis.

INTERPRETATION OF BACTERIOLOGICAL WATER ANALYSES

Two tests are commonly employed in bacteriological water analysis, namely:

(a) Plate count

(b) Estimation of the degree of contamination with coliform organisms. (Small quantities of water containing these organisms are found.)

SIGNIFICANCE OF PLATE COUNTS

The aim of plate counts is to determine the number of organisms in a definite quantity of sample. The results obtained are expressed as the number of colonies per milliliter of water. This method is used when it is desirable to compare the results at various stages of the treatment of water. It is also used to determine whether the water is safe for consumption. The laboratory is desirable, and when the samples arrive packed in ice.

WHY FOCUS ON COLIFORMS ARE REPORTED

Certain bacteria are harmless which normally inhabit the intestinal tract of both man and animal and are passed out in large numbers with the excreta. They, of themselves, do not produce water containing disease germs. However, if the water becomes contaminated by sewage or other organic matter, disease germs such as typhoid, dysentery, etc., may be present. As coliform bacteria always greatly outnumber disease germs, their presence indicates that there may be disease germs present. However, disease germs of this nature are present in such bacteria always accompany them, and usually in large numbers, but they are not always present. Therefore, the presence of coliforms indicates that the water is consequently a more practical procedure than isolating the disease germs themselves.

The presence of coliforms is an indication that the water is potentially dangerous to health.

DETECTION OF CONTAMINATION

In the analysis an attempt is made to determine in what quantities of water these organisms are present. The results are expressed as the number of colonies per milliliter of water. One colony corresponds to about 14,000,000 organisms. The tubes containing the organisms of the water sample and the food materials are incubated for 24 hours at 37°C. The number of colonies present is then counted and compared to determine in what amounts of the water sample coliform bacteria are present. It is evident that the smaller the number of colonies present, the less likely it is that the water contains disease germs.

A water sample which shows coliforms to be present in 1 cc. or less is generally regarded as being contaminated. Water from properly protected or treated supplies show no coliforms in any amount up to and including 50 cc.

INTERPRETATION OF FINDINGS

It is important to remember that the result of a simple bacteriological examination. Contamination may be intermittent and unevenly distributed and consequently water samples frequently show wide variation in the number of coliforms present. No single method is particular to determine the quality of a water supply for drinking purposes. These are:

(1) Single bacteriological examinations

(2) Repeated bacteriological examinations

In a community survey it is important to ascertain the possibility of pollution of the water to human sources such as sewage, septic tanks, and other sources from persons or wastes thrown into the water. If the water is used for irrigation, it may be washed into the water through an improperly constructed pipe. The distance that dangerous organisms can travel depends upon the velocity of the water and the rate of flow of the water. The rate of flow of ground water human pollution is the most dangerous kind, since germs of typhoid fever, paratyphoid, dysentery, etc., are present in large numbers.

Unfortunately, at present no laboratory test can be used to distinguish between coliforms of human origin and those of animal origin. Hence, unless the nature of the contamination is known from the source, it may be impossible to determine the results of the analysis would appear readily the same as if the water were contaminated by the more dangerous human pollution.

For additional information write the Ontario Department of Health, Parliament Street, Toronto.

The building throughout was clean and everything denoted care and attention. The fire hose and equipment was in good condition. The Rev. FORT FRANCES, AGENCY,
JULY, 30th, 1937.

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th Inst.; in which you are inquiring about poultry being kept at the Indian Residential School. And in reply to same, I have to report, that I visited the Fort Frances Indian Residential School, and find that there are no hens kept there and they have no hen house in which to keep them. A few years ago they had hens that stayed in the barn, they were not a success and they disposed of them.

I would like to recommend that a hen house be built for the school, and a number of hens be purchased to give them a start in poultry, and at the same time the pupils be given instruction in the care of poultry.

There are several Indians on the Reserves that have hens and are making a success of their poultry.

I have the honor to be,

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 30th ultimo, the Department will allow an amount of $150 towards the cost of the material for the erection of a henhouse at the Fort Frances Indian Residential School. Dear Doctor Wodehouse:

The attention of the Department has been repeatedly drawn
to the failure on the part of the Department of Indian Affairs to ensure some
satisfactory method of sewage disposal at the Fort Frances Indian Residential
School. The situation is further complicated by the fact that the water supply
for the school is taken from the bay on which the school is situated, at a point
said to be about 1,000 feet distant from the point at which the sewage is
discharged. This water is untreated. Sewage from the institution passes
through a settling tank or septic tank and is discharged without further treatment
into the bay at the point referred to.

Further, the point where the sewage is discharged is quite
close to a summer colony, where bathing is very prevalent in the summer. The
intake pipe for the Town of Fort Frances is also situated at a reasonable distance
from the point of discharge.

The apparent attitude of the Department is that, in view of the
fact that other agencies are discharging untreated waste into the bay, they should
feel perfectly justified in doing so. A continuance of this practice is not
likely to assist this Department in securing any change in the present system of
sewage disposal in adjoining centres. However, the significant point is that the
intimacy of the sewage outfall and the source of water and its proximity to the
neighboring bathing beach, makes for a very serious potential health hazard.

The providing of appropriate treatment for this sewage is
neither involved nor should it be costly. All that would appear to be required
is a filter bed of field tiles, appropriately laid. This could probably be
secured at a cost of $400 or $500. Might I ask if it would be possible for you
to use your good offices in focusing the attention of the Department on this
matter?

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd.) J. T. Phair
(J.T.Phair, M.B., D.P.H.)

Ottawa, January 5, 1936.

Mr. Varde

From time to time this Branch has received complaints regarding the sewage disposal system at the Fort Frances Indian Residential School.

For your information I may say that a report received in 1936 from the Acting Director General of the Dominion Water Power and Hydropower Bureau stated that unrestricted contamination of Rainy River is not permitted at any mills, bathing beaches, summer homes, etc., on both sides of the International Boundary, and that both Fort Frances and International Falls are permitted to discharge immense quantities of raw sewage into Rainy River, contaminating the water supply from that river and also the waters of Lake of the Woods.

It is felt, however, that it would be advisable to make some improvements to the sewage disposal system at the Fort Frances Indian Residential School and an amount of $1,400.00 for this purpose is being provided in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1938-39. The Fort Frances Indian Residential School is located three miles from the Town of Fort Frances, Ontario.

I would appreciate if you would arrange to have one of your engineers visit the Fort Frances School as soon as weather conditions permit next Spring and examine the sewage disposal system. When you receive his report, you might advise me, in order that we can decide if the amount provided in our appropriation will be sufficient to materially improve the condition of the sewage disposal system at this school.

Surveys and Engineering Branch

Ottawa, March 7, 1938.

MR. MILLS,

Re: Proposed Improvement to sewage disposal system, Fort Frances Indian Residential School, Ontario.

In connection with the above I beg to advise that I was requested, while with the Indian Affairs Branch, to examine this proposal as outlined in a report prepared by an engineer of the Winnipeg Office of the Dominion Water and Power Bureau dated July 28th, 1936. This report was submitted upon a request made by the Indian Affairs Branch in a letter dated July 6th, 1936, when an amount of $3400.00 was being provided for in that year's estimates for the above mentioned sewerage work. This new sewage disposal system was taken into consideration on account of the representation made by the Ontario Department of Health that the present one was unsatisfactory and a source of pollution of the Rainy Lake where the effluent from the present cess pool was overflowing at times and discharging into the lake. However, the proposal in question was not given further consideration on account of a recommendation made in the report from Inspector A.G. Hamilton of Winnipeg dated August 6th, 1936, which stated that the present septic tank or cess pool was working satisfactorily, etc.

The Sanitary Engineering Division of the Department of Health was subsequently informed in a departmental letter from Indian Affairs Branch dated October 24th, 1936, that although consideration had been given, that year, to the installation of new sewage disposal systems for the border school it was finally decided not to proceed with the work in 1936 for the reason that unrestricted contamination of Rainy Lake was permitted at saw mills, bathing beaches, and summer homes on both sides of the international boundary as they were allowed to discharge immense quantities of raw sewage into Rainy River thus contaminating the water supply from that river and also the water of the Lake of the Woods as mentioned in a report from the Acting Chief Engineer of the Dominion Water and Power Bureau.

T.S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering and Construction Service,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
The septic tanks designed and constructed by this Bureau at the McIntosh Indian School and the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School near Kenora, contain reinforced steel only in the roof supports and the roofs themselves were not constructed of concrete. They are almost identical in size with that proposed for Fort Frances and apparently they are satisfactory. Later last fall it was necessary to uncover the tanks at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School in order to enlarge the manhole and permit of a cleaning out and it was reported that the eroded 3" plank covering showed no signs of deterioration although it had been underground some nine years.

At Birtle, Brandon, Lebret and Fort Qu'Appelle, all more recent projects, the Institutions were much larger, requiring much larger septic tanks and it became advisable for us to add strong reinforcing in connection with the design and construction of the septic tanks at these four institutions.

I understand that the existing sewage system at the Fort Frances Indian Residential School is not considered unsatisfactory by the School Management but that the complaints, if any, originate with the Ontario Department of Health regarding the pollution of the waters of Rainy Lake. The work which we have outlined, that can be done with an expenditure of $1400.00, is not an immediate necessity in the operation of the school but would prevent the outletting of raw sewage into Rainy Lake. The Ontario Department of Health apparently desire that no pollution of Rainy Lake should take place from this Institution and the work as outlined will not by any means accomplish this purpose.

The work outlined in our report of 1935 and for which $3,400.00 was provided in the 1936 Estimates, would have gone far to meet the requirements of the Department of Health, although we anticipated objections to the idea of passing all kitchen and laundry wastes directly into the lake. The work outlined within the expenditure of $1400.00 will not fit in with the complete disposal scheme should it later be decided to construct the disposal bed and it certainly will not satisfy the complaints regarding the existing layout.

If it is decided to proceed with the expenditure of $1,400.00, we will prepare the necessary plans showing required drains and details of septic tank. Plans showing alterations of plumbing in the school and laundry cannot be prepared as nobody appears to have any knowledge of the present layout. Preparation of plans and etc., however, will not be proceeded with until we have heard further from you.

Yours truly,

(sgd) D.B. Gow.

District Chief Engineer.

WINNIPEG, February 21, 1938.

Dear Sir:

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th instant advising that it is expected an amount of $1400 will be provided in next year's Estimates for the purpose of undertaking some improvement to the present sewage system at the Fort Frances Indian Residential School, and requesting a report from this office as to what improvement work could be carried out with this amount of expenditure.

The situation at the Fort Frances Indian Residential School, as regards the sewage situation, was dealt with in our report of July 5, 1935, and it is not considered that conditions have changed materially since that date. It was pointed out in that report that laundry and kitchen waste and storm water, in addition to its sewage, were thought to pass through the existing septic tank so that a great deal of raw sewage was being passed into Rainy Lake.

It will readily be seen that any proposed improvement work in connection with the sewage system, must provide for separating the kitchen and laundry waste from the sewage and also providing for the storm water so that none of these pass through the septic tank. The present septic tank is obsolete and any improvement work should provide for the construction of a new septic tank. In our report we estimated that this portion of the improvement work would involve an expenditure of $1950.00 or $650.00 more than the amount of money which you say may be provided.

In checking over our estimates of cost as made in 1935, it is not considered that the estimate covering the storm water, laundry and kitchen drain, sewers line to and from the septic tank and alterations in the plumbing in the building, can be lowered. In connection with the septic tank, however, we estimated the cost of this at $1250.00 and made provision for a heavily reinforced structure with reinforced concrete roof, inasmuch as it was expected the tank would be located where considerable traffic would pass over it at times. While eliminating all steel reinforcement, except in the roof supporting beams and substituting 3" pre-cast planking for reinforced concrete for the roof, we could probably reduce the cost of the septic tank to $850.00. This would permit of the work outlined above being carried out with the $1400.00 that may be provided.

T.S. Mills, Esq.,

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: Proposed improvement to sewage disposal system, Fort Frances Indian Residential School.

With reference to the above, I am forwarding herewith copies of reports from Mr. J.D. Chene of the Engineering and Construction Service and from Mr. D.B. Gow, District Chief Engineer, Water and Power Bureau.

It will be seen from these reports that the opinions of Mr. Gow and Mr. Chene are practically the same. It appears that the $1,400.00 suggested will not enable the carrying out of the work which will allow for the complete disposal scheme previously recommended by Mr. Gow at an estimated cost of $3,400.00. Mr. Gow considers, however, that this sum would allow for the construction of a new septic tank to a modified and cheaper design than that originally proposed. This septic tank would, however, not handle waste from kitchen and laundry which would have to pass directly into the lake. There accordingly would appear to be a doubt as to whether the construction of a new septic tank would meet the requirements of the Department of Health. It would seem that careful consideration should be given to the necessity of the expenditure for a fairly large amount of money in order to assure that untreated sewage would not find its way into the lake or river from the Reserve.

I should be glad if you would advise what your Branch wishes to be undertaken next season in order that Mr. Gow may be so instructed.

Sir,

I have the honor to report, that on Monday the 11th day of April, the Principal of the Fort Frances Indian Residential School called me up, in regard to their washing machine. I at once went to the School, and found that their washing machine was nearly a total wreck; the wood I find is all rotten, and falling to pieces; the metal ends are all rusted and leaking; the bolts that hold the machine together are all worn and loose, and cannot be tightened, and in such a state that when trying to wash that something is going to get loose and cause a great deal of damage, or probably injure some of the girls that are doing the washing.

I got in touch with Stanley Brock of Winnipeg, Man., and requested that he send me a quotation on a washing machine that would be required for the School, and enclosed you will find his Quotation on a washer required for this School.

I would recommend that a washer be purchased as soon as possible for this School, because there will certainly be something happen with the washer, and it may be none of the girls that are doing the washing, that will be the victim.

You are acquainted with the washers that are being placed in Residential schools, and I would recommend that one similar should be purchased for this school, and shipped as soon as possible.

I have the honor to be,
Sir,

Dear Dr. McGill:

On the 11th of August last a letter was received from Dr. J. T. Phair, Chief Medical Officer of Health for the Province of Ontario, calling attention to the health hazard present at Fort Frances through the discharge into the Bay of inadequately treated sewage of the Fort Frances Indian Residential School. In his letter he indicated that all that would appear to be required for the adequate treatment of the sewage was a filter bed of field tiles appropriately laid, which could be done at a cost of about $400 or $500. In my absence a copy of Dr. Phair's letter was transmitted to you by the Chief Executive Assistant of this Department.

I am now in receipt of a letter from Dr. Phair pointing out that the time of year is now approaching when such a filter bed can be installed and requesting to be advised if any further information has been received from your department in regard to the action which you propose to take in the matter. I am transmitting a copy of the letter for your consideration.

Yours very truly,

Dear Doctor Bodehouse:

I am in receipt of your letter of April 27 with reference to the letter that you received from Doctor J. T. Phair, Chief Medical Officer of Health for the Province of Ontario, in connection with the treatment of sewage at the Fort Frances Indian Residential School.

In preparing our appropriation for the current fiscal year an amount of $1,400.00 was provided for the purpose of improving the sewage disposal system at this school. However, when we referred the matter to the Surveys & Engineering Branch their engineers visited Fort Frances and reported that they considered that the amount provided was totally inadequate to ensure a satisfactory job and stated that an expenditure of at least $3,400.00 would be necessary. As it was not possible to secure this amount from the current year's appropriation it was decided that no action could be taken.

I note from your letter that Doctor Phair considered that an expenditure of $400.00 or $500.00 would meet the situation. In view of this information I am again taking up the matter with the Surveys & Engineering Branch.

Yours very truly,

H. M. Bodehouse, Esq., M. D.,

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Wardle,

Re: Proposed Improvement to Sewage Disposal System for Fort Frances Indian School.

With reference to your memorandum of the 6th instant enclosing a copy of a memorandum from the Director of Indian Affairs dated the 2nd instant, I may say that a letter was sent to Mr. D.B. Cow, District Chief Engineer of the Water and Power Bureau, Winnipeg, regarding the installation of a disposal bed at a maximum cost of $500, and an answer has now been received.

Mr. Cow is of the opinion that it would not be possible or practicable to construct an effective disposal bed in connection with the existing installation at a cost of $500.00, and he is also of the opinion that it would cost more than this sum to divert the roof and laundry drainage from passing through the septic tank, and into a separate outlet.

Mr. Cow suggests, however, that with the money available, work might be started this year, for diverting the roof and laundry drainage from the septic tank to a separate outlet, and carried as far as funds would permit, as this work is essential in connection with the proposed new disposal system.

Respectfully submitted,

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of [illegible] instant, with reference to sewage treatment at the Fort Frances Indian Residential School.

In our current year's appropriation we provided an amount of $1,400 for improving the sewage disposal system at this school and requested the Surveyors and Engineers Branch to take the necessary action. One of their engineers visited the school and, after carefully surveying the whole situation, reported to us that it was considered the amount we had provided was totally inadequate to ensure a satisfactory job and stated that an expenditure of at least $5,400.00 would be necessary. As it was not possible to secure this amount from the current year's appropriation, it was decided that no action could be taken.

Upon receipt of the letter from Dr. Phair, stating that he considered an expenditure of four or five hundred dollars would meet the situation, the matter was again referred to the Surveyors and Engineers Branch and their engineer again visited the school. His report is now before me and states that it would not be possible or practicable to construct a satisfactory disposal bed for the amount mentioned by Dr. Phair.

I have the honor to report in connection with Voucher No. 280 attached hereto. In connection with this account the Electric Motor that drives the Water Pump for the School and Fire Protection refused to work, and owing to the urgent need of this motor I at once requested Gillmore and Hoden to repair same. Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 7th instant enclosing your voucher No. 280 in connection with repairs to the electric motor and kitchen range in Fort Frances Indian Residential School.

We are prepared to pay this amount, but cannot do so from the voucher which you forwarded. Details will have to be given regarding the repair parts for the school range for which the Company charged $84.15, and the item of $12.55 which covers labour. In this case the date on which Gillmor & Noden made the repairs should be stated, also the number of hours the workmen were employed and the rate per hour.

When you have the account properly itemized, you should return it for payment. For your information, I may say that when the cheque for this is issued, the full amount provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at the Fort Frances Residential School will have been expended, and it will not be possible to consider any further expenditure.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

Reverend Father P. Chatelain, the new principal of the Fort Frances Indian Residential School is desirous of furnishing his chapel with pews. The pupils now use old style benches that are very uncomfortable and unsightly.

I am enclosing a quotation from the J. A. Mathieu Limited of Rainy Lake, Ontario, for the lumber for these pews. The balance of the material needed for these pews would not amount to more than $30.00; that would include, nails, screws and varnish.

Father Chatelain advises me that the making of these pews in his own school would furnish the older boys occasion to be trained in carpentry.

Hoping that you will be able to supply this material, I remain,

Dear Sir:

May I acknowledge your letter of March 31st, which, unfortunately, had been mislaid and has just come to light. In this you mentioned what further treatment might be given at Fort Frances Indian residential school.

The situation, as observed by our officials sometime ago, was that there were approximately one hundred in residence in the school and that there was at the time a septic tank in operation but the effluent from this tank discharged directly into the lake without getting further treatment.

The proposal that we had in mind was that, providing this tank was large enough, and we have no information to the contrary, all that would be required would be to lay open-joint field tile between the tank and the lake. There is an area of some considerable width on which these tiles might be laid. They should be laid parallel with the water and the rows might be placed three to four feet apart. For this purpose it would be necessary to have about 3,000 feet of 4" tile. The soil is quite sandy here and if these tiles are laid at a depth of approximately 2 to 2½ feet they should give quite satisfactory results. The cost of this should be quite moderate and would not exceed $500.00 under ordinary circumstances.

Yours very truly,

He states that the tank has the necessary two compartments, but that it is not equipped with the proper fittings to withhold the solid matter on one side to be treated, before passing through the second compartment in a soluble state. Unless these repairs are made the 3000 feet of weeping tile would clog.

The cost of 3000 feet of 4" tile would cost $350.00 and the laying of this tile could be done by the Indians at a cost of approximately $200.00 for labour.

Trusting that this is the information you require, I am

Yours very truly,

J.F. Lockhart,
Fort Frances Indian Agency.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 15th instant with reference to the sewage disposal plant at the Fort Frances residential school.

As you are aware all purchases have to be made through our Purchasing Branch and I should, therefore, appreciate more detailed information regarding the 4 inch tile. What is the length of each tile? Does the 4 inch refer to the inside or outside measurements? Can this tile be secured locally? If so, give the name and address of the firm. Please let me have this information at the earliest possible date in order that I may arrange for immediate purchase by the Purchasing Branch.

I understand from your letter that only Indian labour will be required. If any white labour is required you should let me know the number of men that would be necessary and the approximate time that they would be working.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

J. F. Lockhart, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Fort Frances, Ont.
Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter No. 124-1-5 of the 21st instant, please be advised that the 4" tile is the inside measurement. The length of each tile is one foot, and can be purchased locally from the John East Co., Ltd., Fort Frances.

Mr. East, who is a contractor, sees no reason why the Indians cannot do the digging and laying of tile themselves. He is willing to go up to the school and instruct the Indians on laying the tile at the proper slope so that there will be no rush of water to the end, but allowed to seep through the full length of the drain.

As there are no flanges or locking joints on weeping tile, it is customary to wrap a piece of tar paper at the end of each tile to protect any dirt from falling into the drain when the trench is refilled.

Trusting that this is the information that you require, I am

Yours very truly,

J.F. Lockhart,
Fort Frances Indian Agency.

Dear Sir:

Re: Sewage Disposal at the Fort Frances Indian Residential School.

I regret to advise that the above mentioned work has been suspended for the present, due to the fact that the information supplied by the Department of Health, Toronto, which was contained in your letter No. 124-1-5, July 4th, 1939, was not correct.

From the extract as shown in your letter, they state that field tile placed from 2 to 2½ feet deep would give satisfactory results, and it was on this basis that we estimated $200.00 for labour to trench and lay 3000 feet of tile.

Before commencing this work we had Mr. Kay, Field Officer from the Department of Health, come to Fort Frances and outline the work. After Mr. Kay examined the Septic Tank, he stated that the field tile would have to be placed 9 feet deep, owing to the construction and depth of the tank. At this depth no drainage could be had, as the tile would then be in clay. Also, at that depth there would be danger of seepage from the lake.

Mr. Kay, who appears to have had considerable experience with septic tanks, advises that no work be started at present, as the $200.00 allowed would be of no value.

I have requested Mr. Kay to forward a detailed report of exactly what is required and I would suggest that you take this matter up with the Department of Health, Toronto, who by this date should be in possession of all the particulars.

The tile and septic tank fittings are on the ground, ready for installation, when a solution can be arrived at.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Upon receipt of your Night Letter received yesterday, concerning difficulty encountered with sewage and pumping water at the Fort Frances Indian Residential School, I proceeded to the School and had a plumber accompany me.

We found the pumping facilities in good order. Pumps were started and tanks filled in the usual length of time. The Principal admitted that the pumps were working alright now. A week or ten days ago they did have difficulty in getting water and upon inspection a fish was found in the intake pipe, having slipped through the check-valve or it may have grown in the pipe. However, since this was removed the pumping has been O.K.

Another complaint he had was that hot water was to be found in the cold water pipes. This can be understood, as a new hot water tank was installed recently and being free from any corrosion, heats faster and supplies more hot water than they are using. When the pressure rises in the hot water tank it forces the hot water back through the cold water pipes as it is the only place it can go and circulates through the building. When the same situation arises in a town residence, the hot water backs up and is forced out into the main, but at the school where there is no main it has to go back to the water tanks. This can be overcome by placing a check-valve on the cold water pipe at the hot water tank and a safety valve placed on the hot water tank, then when the pressure rises in the tank it sets off the safety valve as it cannot back through the cold water intake pipe.

The sewage had been blocked and backed up in the school. Water had risen in one room and filled the school with odor.

Upon enquiries yesterday I found out that the school does not supply the children with toilet paper but gives them old newspaper. I believe a lot of their trouble with the sewage blocking is due to this practice, when one realizes the amount of newspaper put into the sewage by 88 children.
Toronto, October 21, 1934.

Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Superintendent of Welfare & Training,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th enclosing a copy of a letter from J. F. Lockhart of Fort Frances.

When our Mr. Kay was at Fort Frances, and when the tank was dug up it was found that the outlet tile was at a considerably greater depth than was anticipated.

I might point out that it was impossible for this department to get any information on this originally, no one seemed to know what plans had been made.

Obviously, it is not desirable or feasible to put these tiles at a depth of 9 feet. The cost would be high and it would be difficult to get drainage. What was suggested when our Mr. Kay was there was an air well chamber installed, and an electrically operated pump be placed in this. This would lift the water from the tank to the tile bed. The tiles could then be laid near the surface, and good results could be expected. This will add to the cost somewhat but it will not be a large figure. Mr. Kay, at the time of his visit gave explicit instructions to the principal of the school, and no great difficulty should be involved in having this installed.

If there is any doubt about any particular point please let me know.

I wish to bring to your attention the items on the enclosed invoice, which are listed under "work on Intake".

When John East submitted his estimate for installing new pipes in the water intake leading from the lake, the water level was low. Dear Sir,

Rev. Father Provencher and the principal of the Fort Frances Indian Residential School, called today to discuss the sewage disposal situation. I understand this matter has been placed before the Department for their consideration and that estimates have been obtained in connection with a disposal field and also for supplying an electric pump for the purpose of pumping the sewage from the septic tank.

There seems to be considerable doubt in the minds of the Principal and the Rev. Father Provencher as to the best method of handling the situation. In view of the information I have, I would like to suggest that a further expression of opinion be obtained from an engineer of the Dominion Water Power Branch.

After a decision has been made as to what action should be taken, I am convinced that the most satisfactory and the most economical way of carrying out the work, would be to allow the school authorities permission to employ Mr. Desrochers, who the Department already know as foreman on several building enterprises which have been carried out during the past two or three years. I believe the Rev. Father principal would be willing to submit a quotation, and if the work were undertaken by them, it would be carried out to their entire satisfaction. I believe the sewage has backed up into the school on different occasions and this matter should be attended to without further delay.

I would be glad to know where this matter stands and what action the Department decide to take.

Dear Sir:

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 124-1-5 of the 18th instant, relative to proposed work on diverting the sewage at the Indian Residential School.

The season is too far advanced to continue this work this fall, as the frost is now in the ground and digging would be slow work and the cost greater.

I would recommend that this work be suspended until the frost is out next spring. In the meantime the Sanitary Engineering Division could prepare a plan showing in detail just what should be done to give satisfactory results.

In the opinion of local men, the outlet of 1½" in the pump suggested by the Sanitary Division, is not large enough. They contend that this pump is designed for handling water only, but for the particular work required here, there would always be the danger of a hard substance or paper getting into the pumping chamber and blocking such a small outlet. Then again, this pump is only 3'5" over all, which would result in it having to be installed approximately 6' below the surface.

The Principal can offer no information regarding installation and insists that he never was instructed in this connection.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I have received two copies of letters which have been sent to the Department by Joseph Lambert and the Sisters at the Residential School.

This morning while at the School, I was surprised to learn that Mr. Lambert had written the above mentioned letter, denying, that he had ever told me that the water and sewage were working O.K. I had the Principal call Mr. Lambert and when confronted, he admitted that he had told me the water and sewage were working O.K. on my visit to the school, the day the Principal was absent in Winnipeg. He added that he only meant everything was O.K. the day I enquired.

With regard to the letter sent by the Sisters, I can only say that this letter refers to conditions that has existed over a period of two years. That for the past month no stoppage has occurred in the sewage. In fact, not since toilet paper has been supplied by the school management.

I have done my best to correct trouble at the school and have reported my findings just as I found them. The Principal agrees that I have done all that I can. I explained to the Principal, that I am not a plumber or steam-fitter, and that I have to depend on the reports of the men who make the repairs.

Sunday morning the Principal called in the Plumber as they could not get any water. The trouble was not in the intake line as suspected, but the pump was not operating properly. This morning when called to the school the Principal stated that they were again without water. The pump was started in my presence and water obtained. This was the third time I have been called to the school re water trouble and on each occasion they were able to obtain water while I was there. However, the Principal states that the pump does not work all the time, but that it takes spells of starting and stopping.

The Principal is not at all satisfied with the way in which the pumps etc. are working and has requested that a qualified engineer be sent from Winnipeg to check all equipment.

I would gladly recommend that such a man be sent, if possible, and thus get to the bottom of the trouble at the school.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find account received from John East covering repair work done at the Fort Frances Indian Residential School.

On November 6th, I received a telephone call from the Principal of the school, requesting that I go out to the school as they were having trouble in securing water. On my arrival at the school I found a plumber and two other men working on the water line. They had been called early Sunday morning by the Principal. They had worked all day Sunday in an endeavour to locate the stoppage but were unsuccessful up to Monday morning. As the school was badly in need of water for the toilets etc., they were rigging up a temporary line in order that the school tanks could be filled. Eventually they cleared the stoppage which was between the shore and 1800 feet out in the lake. The hole that was dug down to the line at the shore was boxed in so that in case a stoppage occurs again, a force pump can be attached and the obstruction cleared with very little expense.

Yours very truly,

J.F. Lockhart,

Fort Frances, Ont., Jan. 16th, 1934

Dear Sir:

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 12th instant.

On receipt of this letter I immediately got in touch with John East, to accompany me to the school. Mr. East was tied up on a heating job at the time and could not leave, but assured me that as soon as he was free he would let me know.

This morning, Mr. East and his plumber went to the school with me. We obtained the keys for the pump house from the Principal. The pump was started and an ample supply of water obtained immediately. I enquired of the man in charge of pumping, just what trouble they were having. He stated, that at times it was necessary to prime the pump before they could get water. Also, that at times the pump misses and that it was necessary to prime again to pick up the water. This fault only happens occasionally. I asked him just when it occurred last and he informed me that it had not happened the last five days at least. Mr. East explained to him that all high pressure pumps require priming and that they will miss occasionally. There is no trouble with the sewage blocking and there has been no stoppage during the past six weeks.

Since the Department authorized the installation of a check valve on the cold water pipe and a safety valve on the hot water tank, there has been no recurrence of hot water getting into the cold water pipes.

Finally, as inspected today, there was no trouble to be found with either the water supply or sewage disposal. Mr. East will gladly submit a letter verifying this report, if requested.

Yours very truly,

J.F. Lockhart,
Clerk in Charge.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

The Fort Frances Indian Residential School is situated 3 miles from the town of Fort Frances and on the shore of Rainy Lake. For the past 5 or 6 years the District Medical Health Officer of the Province of Ontario has been complaining that the sewage from the school is not properly treated before discharge into the lake and as a consequence contaminates the water. Mr. Gow made an investigation in 1935 and estimated that it would require $3,400.00 to provide a proper system.

Since the time of Mr. Gow's report we have not been able to include in our appropriation an amount sufficient to carry out the work in the manner suggested by Mr. Gow. However, in the meantime the Provincial medical authorities have continued to criticise our system of sewage disposal. Early this year we wrote to them and stated that the reasons for not taking any action was due to the fact that our engineer had suggested an expenditure of $3,400.00 which it was not possible to provide. In reply the Provincial Department of Health stated that it was unnecessary to expend such a large amount and in a letter addressed to the acting Indian Agent, Mr. Lockhart, recommended the following:

1 metal tank one quarter size of septic tank and installing same below the overflow level of septic tank, also installing small sump pump and float controls.

Mr. John Mast, General Contractor and Sanitary Engineer, has forwarded a quotation of $451.88 for carrying out the work suggested by the Provincial Department of Health.
Funds to the above amount are available in the current year's appropriation and I should appreciate receiving the Minister's approval to proceed with the work at once in order that the installation may be made before the cold weather sets in.

[Signature]
Director.

Dr. McGill -

Referring to the above, the Minister approves of this work being proceeded with if you are satisfied that the cost will not exceed the amount estimated by the Sanitary Engineer Mr. John East who, it is understood, is an official of the Provincial Department of Health. It might be well for you, however, to have the Surveys and Engineering Branch examine into the plan proposed by him to remedy the situation now existing.

[Signature]
Chief Executive Assistant.

AIR MAIL

Re: Sewerage Disposal at Fort Frances Indian Residential School

Dear Sir:

I visited the above school last week and wish to submit the following information and recommendations.

The disposal bed is laid ready for use. However, before it is connected, I am convinced the water from the school roof together with the laundry water should be diverted from the septic tank. This volume of water I fear will destroy the chemical action of the tank and will keep the automatic pump in the septic tank working all the time.

I attach a sketch showing the school, and would recommend that Agent Lockhart be instructed to take the roof water by tile to the lake from both front corners of the school. Mr. Lockhart has tile, and sufficient money left over from installing the disposal bed, to do this work. The extra required would be labour for repairing eave troughing and supplying some extra round pipe to carry the water from the rear of the roof.

The laundry water could be taken to the corner of the laundry and across the playground, 275 feet to the lake. This work, if authorized, could be done by Indians, except the plumbing work inside the laundry. The Indians could take up the cement floor and have everything ready for the plumber. The tile required should, I think, be 6" glazed tile. The digging and laying of the tile could be supervised by Agent Lockhart. The tile costs about 45¢ per foot, f.o.b. Winnipeg, less 10%.

Considerable money has already been spent, and I recommend that Mr. Lockhart be advised at once concerning the above recommendations. The land in this district is soaked with water and I am sure the disposal bed will be unable to handle the situation unless we relieve it of as much water as possible. It might also be advisable to obtain advice from Mr. Gooch of the Dominion Water Power, or some other competent Engineer.

The work at this school should be completed, and I would request instructions be issued at once to Mr. Lockhart authorising the necessary expense.

Yours very truly,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

The Secretary,

Enclosed please find account received from John East re work performed on Sewage Diversion at the Fort Frances Indian Residential School.

I beg to offer the following explanation regarding several small items of expenditure.

When laying the field tile it was necessary to wrap each connection with tar paper to prevent sand and dirt from getting into the pipes, hence the charge of $11.70 for this material.

When the plumber installed the soil pipe diverting the laundry water from septic tank to sewer pipe, the concrete floor had to be replaced in the laundry and the items of $2.00 and $3.00 cover material used for this purpose. The work was done by Indian labour.

The laying of sewer pipe was also done by Indian labour and we found that it would be necessary to have a boxing made of wood at the outlet to the lake, otherwise the pipe if left exposed would freeze and break. The items of $6.32 - .30¢ and .12¢ were for material used for this purpose. Also, the item of $14.40 covers oakum required to pack joints in sewer pipe.

Dear Sir:

Report for the month of October 1941.

The weather during the most part of the month was cold and wet. It was the first time on record that flood conditions occurred in the fall of the year in this district.

The septic tank and lift pump which was installed at the Indian Residential School is working satisfactory but the field tile cannot take the water from the tank, with the land being so wet and the lake so high the tile bed is full of water. I had the Indians dig two lateral drains from the pump to carry off the water. This has worked quite well so far but I am afraid if it freezes hard we will experience further difficulties.

J.F. Lockhart,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of November 17th with reference to the roofing material for the repair work to be carried out at the Indian Residential School at Fort Frances, Ontario.

As requested in your letter, we inquired of Building Products Limited whether the standard thick butt twin shingles could be made available. After some delay we were informed that they now have available a sufficient quantity of such shingles to meet your order but not of one color. They would have to supply equal quantities of two colors, presumably red and green. They could not say how long the supply would be available or advise as to the prospects of any supply being available after these have been disposed of.

I do not believe the above mentioned shingles could be satisfactorily placed under the weather conditions that now prevail, for they become quite brittle with low temperatures. Furthermore, I believe you will find it difficult to carry out the roofing job on the school with any material during the winter months.

It is possible that some shingles will be available for shipment to dealers before March 21st next but orders for the same must be placed early. I telephoned Mr. Carter and suggested he write his people at the Coast to see if possibility of there being some shingles available by spring. He agreed to do so and I would suggest that you place your order for shingles with Mr. Carter as soon as possible if it is decided not to utilize a substitute material for roofing.

It is possible that you have the men available to carry out the roofing job under winter conditions but I understand the labor situation in your town is such that younger men are not available and accordingly this job with older men only available might be difficult. Should the Ottawa officials desire the work to proceed with composition shingles and you are agreeable to proceeding during the winter, I believe the material will be available. Personally, I would suggest that the work might advantageously be postponed until spring; every effort being made in the meantime to procure B. O. Cedar Shingles. If these are not available by March 1st, they will not be obtainable after that date and I think Building Products Limited could then arrange to supply their product. I do not know whether the Ottawa officials would approve of the use of such material for I believe Cedar Shingles are much to be preferred.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) D. B. Gow

With reference to your memorandum of February 16th, relative to the above and confirming telephone conversation with Mr. Phelan this morning, I may say that the proposal of the principal of the school has been referred to our Engineering and Construction Service for report.

Mr. Mills points out that he has been advised that there has been an extremely severe winter at Fort Frances with very heavy snow fall and that it would not be unreasonable therefore to assume that the reported serious leakages are the result of thermal action from the interior of the building on accumulated snow and ice on the roof, causing water to back up under the shingles producing leakages through the gambrel roof or at the side walls of the dormers. This action will occur even on a new roof and points at which moisture is evident in the habitable parts of the building are not necessarily an indication of where water is coming in. There is thus no assurance that spot repairs which apparently Father Chatelain has in mind would be effective.

We would recommend the removal of snow and ice deposits from all roof surfaces, this would probably eliminate the trouble and should be carried out immediately on authority of the Indian Agent before any expenditure on spot repairs is incurred.

The John East Estate which has the contract for the repairs to the roof has advised that they have reason to
believe their order for shingles will be shipped from the Coast early in March and that we can rest assured the work will be commenced just as soon as the weather permits. It is improbable, however, that the work can be completed by March 31st. We would suggest, therefore, that half of the $1600 allotted to this project be released to your Branch for other purposes and the remaining $800 be retained for use as a progress payment to the contractors when material is delivered. Kindly advise if this suggestion regarding funds is agreeable to you.

We would also recommend that no action regarding the principal's proposal be taken for the present and that your Branch make no independent arrangements with Father Chatelain.

Director.
Ottawa,

Date May 3rd, 1944
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Water Main to Residential School.

In 1922 the Department of Indians Affairs sold a portion of Agency Reserve Lot by public auction and summer homes were erected on same. These property owners are very anxious to have the Town of Fort Frances extend their water main to service these homes and the Town has consented to undertake this work providing the Indian Residential School together with the property owners agree to pay a portion of the cost of construction.

The Town is prepared to take the water to the end of the leased portion that was obtained for park purposes, and the other parties would be required to pay the cost from there to the school. The distance from where the Town would stop to the school would be 360 feet. At a cost of $2.50 per foot, which covers the laying of 6" main together with hydrants etc., would be a total of $914.00.

The property owners are prepared to pay $3000.00 towards this work, considering that they only use their summer homes for about three months of the year, they came to a fair percentage to pay.

I have been requested to bring this matter to the Department's attention and see if they would consider paying the balance, or approximately $6000.00 to have a good water supply at the school.

The present water supply at the School is obtained direct from the Lake, through pipe extending some 1800 feet out from the shore. This intake was installed in 1905 and has not been very satisfactory the last few years, as fish get up in the line and have to be removed. It is not a dependable source of supply in case of fire.

I would appreciate an early reply so that I may acquaint the Town and property owners the Department's views in this connection.

[Signature]

[Name] Agent.
Ottawa, July 7, 1944.

Mr. A. G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
556 Dominion Public Building, Winnipeg, Manitoba.

I enclose, for your information, copy of a letter received from Indian Agent Larkham, Fort Frances, Ont. He is being advised that as no provision was made for this expenditure in the current year's appropriation, it is not possible for the Department to give favourable consideration to his suggestion.

However, it would be appreciated if you would find it possible to investigate the matter more thoroughly, with a view to advising us if you believe we should give consideration in our appropriation next year to providing the necessary funds.

I am particularly interested in the division of the costs. I feel that the amount requested from us is out of proportion to the amount the property holders in the summer resort are prepared to pay.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

R. A. Hoey,

Fort Frances, Ont., August 23rd, 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I have just returned from visiting the Fort Frances Indian Residential School. The School Management was busy repairing the flooring in Classroom No. 1, which had become heaved and warped.

The desks in this room are very old and broken. They were supplied in 1906 and the Principal informs me that they have been trying to have them replaced for the past 11 years. Since they are repairing the floor and have all the old desks out, would it be at all possible to have new ones put in at this time. If funds are available I would recommend that purchase be made now.

They also require two new charts which are yellow with age and worn out. A new Beacon Phonetic Chart to be used in preparation for work of the New Beacon Primer 1. Also a New Beacon Reading Chart to be used for the work of the New Beacon Primer. These charts are by James H. Passatt and are published by Ginn & Co., London, New York etc. These charts are yellow with age and torn and should be replaced.

A list of seats required is attached herewith, together with page 6, from Koyen's catalogue No. 58-7, 1942-43.

Please advise the Department's decision in this connection and oblige.

Re: Proposed New Water Line from Fort Frances to the Indian School

Your letter dated July 7th, 1944,
File 124-15.

During my recent inspection of the Fort Frances area I discussed this matter with Mr. Lockhart, Mr. Frank Stewart, (Sec.-Treas. of the Township of Mulroney),
Walter Gagnon, John Mooney and the Principal of the school.

I attach a sketch which will help to make the situation clearer. From the nearest connection to the corner of the land owned by the summer campers is approximately 1600 feet. Fort Frances will bring the water line to that point and the town citizens will be assessed for the cost. The campers are also citizens of Fort Frances so will share in this expense. Then the distance along the camp grounds is shown on the map - approximately 2850 feet. From that to the school is 1000 feet, or a total of 3850 feet. The proposed cost is at the rate of $2.50 per foot, or $9,125.00. The property owners, some of whom do not even have a house on their lot, are prepared to pay $2,000.00 in addition to their assessment on the 1500 feet assessed by the town. This will leave approximately $6,100.00 as our share.

These camp "property owners" can lay a surface pipe line which will meet their needs for a much smaller investment; but are prepared to spend more for a permanent piece of work.

If we were to look ahead over a period of ten years this proposal might pay dividends. At present we have a pipe line into the lake about 1800 feet long. The water is pumped into two large pressure tanks, both of which may be twenty years old. The pipe line has given some trouble, also the pump, and if we were forced to renew the present system the expense would perhaps reach four or five thousand dollars.
Then with this system we have no outside fire protection. All our fire hose and equipment is inside where the fire is most likely to occur. Again the children and staff are drinking untreated lake water. I doubt if the Public Health Authorities will allow this to continue much longer. Then lastly there is the continual repair and upkeep.

Now against this we would pay about $6100.00 and receive a water main, the property of Fort Frances and so their responsibility and upkeep. We would have a six inch main and a hydrant outside the school. This would greatly improve our fire protection. We would also have properly chlorinated water - a safeguard to the health of all. The upkeep would be eliminated; but we would be obliged to pay for the water and this brought some objection from the principal.

The Council promised to submit a price on the water; but this has not yet arrived. I will forward the same as soon as received. I might just add that unless the same councillors are elected to carry on in 1945 it is doubtful if the above proposals will receive consideration.

A.C. Murray,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.
Ottawa,

The proposed new water line from Fort Frances, as outlined in Mr. Hamilton's letter of November 24th last, is worthy of consideration. As pointed out above, the present water supply affords little in the way of fire protection. The sewage disposal system at the school undoubtedly passes the effluent from the septic tank directly into the lake at or about the location of the water intake pipe. While the water intake originally was extended to good water, the situation now may be serious if breaks have occurred within a few hundred feet of the shore line. It is altogether probable that a new intake will be required at the school, also a new pump and some greater measure of fire protection. If it is found that a new intake is required following the making of the tests, then serious consideration should be given to the proposal to connect up with the Fort Frances water system.

It is not definitely known what the daily use of water at the school may be but it is probably quite high due to the fact that there has been no necessity for conservation and it might average 6,000 to 10,000 gallons daily. At $5 per 1,000 gallons, the yearly cost would be from $300.00 to $750.00.

We will communicate further with you with respect to this water supply as soon as a test has been made as to the continued use of the present intake.

(Sgd.) D. B. Cow
D. B. Cow,
District Chief Engineer.
The writer visited the above mentioned school on August 30th and made inquiries of the Principal and the engineer as regards the water supply. The water supply situation was also discussed with Mr. Lockhart, Indian Agent at Fort Frances.

The present intake consists of a 2" Cast Iron pipe extending out into Rainy Lake, probably 1500 to 1800 feet. This pipe was laid many years ago before Rainy Lake was raised to its present level and there is nothing to indicate the location of the pipe line. The pump, driven by a 1 HP motor, feeds into two pressure tanks and when the school is in operation the pump must be in operation almost continuously throughout the day time. Because of the small sized intake and small capacity of pump, there is very little fire protection afforded the school.

The Principal of the School advised that last spring there were complaints to him from the laundry of dirt and sand in the water, that there was a large deposit of sand in the pressure tanks necessitating frequent cleaning and that the sand scoured the pump cylinders necessitating frequent overhauling. There was also some complaint as to water insects from the lake and about the matter same time previous of the presence of fish somewhere in the water system. The Engineer at the school advised that he cleaned the tanks about every second year and the sand usually less than 2" of sand and dirt removed from the bottom of the tanks. There appeared to be no complaint as to the quality of water at the time of my visit.

It is quite possible and very probable, that the pipe line is broken at one or more points between the pump and the original intake and that the water supply is being pumped without benefit of any screening. If such breaks exist, it is considered quite possible and advisable to locate the same by emptying one of the pressure tanks and by operation of the air compressor force air into the intake pipe and out through any breaks that may occur. At the time of my visit the men were busy Taylor but Mr. Lockhart agreed to have the compressed air test made as soon as possible and to advise this office as to the results. If such tests show breaks have not occurred within 1,000 feet of the present shore line, then it should be possible to locate the break and with the aid of a diver affix a new screen and elevate the end of the pipe so as to eliminate the pumping of sand, dirt and insects. This expedient, if successfully carried out, will enable the school to carry on with the same water supply system as at present in use.

T. S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering and Construction Service,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.
MEMORANDUM:

Re: Fort Frances Indian Residential School

Referring to your notation on a copy of a memorandum from Indian Affairs dated July 20th, we are now in receipt of a report from Mr. Gow dated September 10th, duplicate copies of which are attached.

It seems likely that the present intake pipe is broken or that the screen at the suction end needs replacement. Mr. Gow recommends that a test of this pipe be made with air forced through from the compressor to determine the location of the broken section of pipe and Mr. Lockhart has agreed to have this done.

If it is discovered that the breaks have taken place in the intake pipe within a few hundred feet of the shore there is danger of contamination from the effluent of the septic tank. If the breaks have occurred at or close to the suction end of the pipe these might possibly be repaired.

However there seems to be a distinct possibility that a new intake, also a new pump and a greater measure of fire protection will be required for the school, in which case the proposal to connect to the Fort Frances water system should be given serious consideration.

If the Indian Affairs Branch should eventually decide to take water for the school from the Fort Frances system they should be prepared for water charges of at least $600.00 per year at least until the school authorities are able to train the staff and the students in methods of water conservation.

Definite recommendations in this matter are expected from Mr. Gow when the result of the test by compressed air is known and you will be further advised.

Chief Engineer.

Director,

Memorandum:

Re: Fort Frances Indian Residential School.

The following has been received from Mr. Cow under date of November 9th:

"We have for reply your letter of October 22nd with reference to the above mentioned subject and asking to be advised as to the further report as mentioned in the last paragraph of our letter of September 10th. Upon receipt of your letter, we wrote Mr. Lockhart, Indian Agent at Fort Frances, with reference to the securing of the test mentioned and we are now advised that there are two check valves in the intake pipe, one at the shore line about six feet underground and another in the pump house so that it is not possible to force air out the intake by means of the treasure tank system. Accordingly, if we proceed further with the testing of the water line it will be necessary to dig down at the valve near the shore line and force oil out through the intake. It is not considered feasible to do what at this time. We will give further consideration to the matter next spring at the time of lower water conditions on Rainy Lake.

"In the meantime we do not consider that there is any urgent need for any adjustment of the water supply system at this school."

We believe the suggestion to use oil to test out the suction pipe should be carefully considered as to its possible effect on the water supply before adopting this method. You will note the final paragraph of the quotation above.

It will, I believe, be possible and advisable for the Indian Affairs Branch to conclude an agreement with the Town of Fort Frances to supply town water to the Indian School. The proposed arrangement must provide for the laying of a new 6" water main, the installation of hydrants in close proximity to the farm buildings and the Indian School. The Town should be responsible for maintenance of the main and hydrants and should collect water rates at an approximate cost of 10¢ to 12¢ per thousand gallons used. While the principle of a Government grant towards such a project is open to question, it must be realized that the agreement cannot be made unless some suitable grant is made and accordingly an amount of $6,000.00 is suggested. It is imperative for the Town of Fort Frances to get delivery of 6" Anthes pipe or 6" transite pipe before the spring of 1947; even were they to place an order now, so that some agreement should be made so as to ensure delivery of the necessary pipe during 1947.

The water supply situation at this time at the school is decidedly unsatisfactory. An effort will have to be made to locate the 2" intake pipe and to secure water through this line. If such efforts are unsuccessful, then it is advisable to lay a new 2" main at least 400 feet out into the lake and to protect such intake against freezing conditions during the coming winter. Such measures will permit the water supply being secured until a new main can be laid but it will not provide the school with any more measure of fire protection than they have at present, nor will it ensure a supply of safe water for use.

I would appreciate receiving advice from you at an early date as to whether or not the Indian Affairs Branch are desirous of an agreement being reached with the Town of Fort Frances along the lines above mentioned.

Re: Water Supply, Fort Frances Indian Residential School, Fort Frances, Ontario.

The information available in this office relative to a proposed new water line from Fort Frances to the Indian Residential School was limited to the letters of November 24, 1944 and March 29, 1945 from Inspector Hamilton of Winnipeg to the Indian Affairs Branch at Ottawa. Inspector Hamilton's discussions apparently were not with officials of the Town of Fort Frances but rather with officials of the Township of McIrvine in which the Indian School is located.

This correspondence shows that a new pipe line about 5,150 feet in length was necessary. Of this new main, 1,500 feet in Fort Frances would be constructed and maintained by the Town of Fort Frances in order to ensure a water supply and fire protection for their buildings in the tourist park. For 2,650 feet the line would be in the Township of McIrvine and thence 1,000 feet to the Indian School. The estimated cost of this 3,650 feet was about $8,000.00 of which the number land owners, resident in McIrvine Township, were to pay $5,000.00 and the Indian Affairs Branch $3,000.00. The Township did not pay any of the cost but would collect $5 per 1,000 gallons for all water used and for which they would be responsible for upkeep and maintenance of this portion of the line, that is, 3,650 feet.

Upon calling at the Town Hall at Fort Frances on June 12th to see the Clerk about a possible water supply from the Town, he informed the writer that the Council was just commencing a session and requested that I discuss the matter with the Mayor and Council in person. In the discussion which followed, I found that the Mayor and Council were whole heartedly in favour of any proposal to extend their water supply to the Indian Residential School. They desired to have a 6" main extended in order to provide fire protection to the buildings in their tourist park and also that the permanent residents of Fort Frances with summer homes along the lake in McIrvine Township might enjoy the advantages of an adequate and safe water supply and also because they realized that the Indian Residential School, although situated in McIrvine Township, was a contributing factor in the commercial life of Fort Frances. It was pointed out to the Council that my visit to Fort Frances had not been made with any expectation of discussing this matter with them and that we were merely desirous of obtaining data upon which we could make suggestions to Ottawa as to what might best be done to overcome the rather unsatisfactory water supply situation at the school. The subject was discussed later with the Town officials and I expressed the view that I would prefer to conclude an agreement with the Town of Fort Frances to build and maintain the new water main and make the levy for water rates which should not exceed a cost of 10¢ per 1,000 gallons used. The officials were also heartily in favour of excluding the Township of McIrvine from any such agreement.

There is no possibility of connecting up the water supply system of this school with the Fort Frances water supply until 1947 at the earliest, due to the inability of the Municipality to obtain the necessary pipe. It is necessary, therefore, to ensure an adequate water supply at the school for September 1st next, and this water supply must be such that stoppage will not be experienced during the winter. The present intake of 2" pipe is said to extend 1800 feet into the lake and was laid many years ago when the water was about 7 feet lower than at present. Lumbering companies have booming areas nearby and their alligators are thought to have disturbed this line with their dragging anchors. Some very few years ago a test was made of this pipe line by Mr. Smith of the John East Company of Fort Frances. Oil was forced out through the intake line and the test showed that oil came out of the pipe line at a long distance from shore, presumably at the outer end of the line. If at all possible, the existing intake should be located and the intake cleared. The present intake from the school to the water's edge is clear of obstructions and about 15 feet underground but at the water's edge it dips steeply underground into the lake and to lay a new line at this time under the water at this point would involve considerable coffer dam work. The location of the pipe line is not known but if it is could be located and broken, even as close as 1,000 feet to shore, a diver could affix a new intake screen and thus permit of an adequate water supply until other arrangements could be carried out.

In a following letter the proposal to derive a water supply for this school from Fort Frances is dealt with. It is anticipated that a very satisfactory arrangement can be made with the Town of Fort Frances and it is unfortunate that the inability to secure the necessary pipe line for the extension will not permit of the connection being made during the present year.

Re: Water Supply, Fort Frances Indian Residential School, Fort Frances, Ontario.

On June 12th and 13th visits were made by Mr. G. M. Lyon of this staff and the writer to the Fort Frances Indian Residential School and on the 12th the writer met the Mayor and Council of Fort Frances in connection with a proposal to extend the Fort Frances water supply system to the Indian Residential School.

The visit to the school on the 12th disclosed that a few days previously the water supply had failed completely due to the intake pipe being plugged at whatever point water had previously been drawn. As a temporary measure the school engineers had excavated down to the 2" intake pipe in the vicinity of the water's edge and at the location of the relief valve had laid one - 20 foot length of 1" pipe out into the lake in order to secure a water supply for the school. The writer arranged with the Town Engineer of Fort Frances to send their air compressor to the school on the morning of the 13th and it was connected with the 2" intake pipe beyond the check valve at the water's edge. Although over 100 pound pressure was applied, they were unable to clear the intake pipe and because of the rough water on the lake, escaping air bubbles could not be detected. The air compressor would cut in at 90 pounds and shut off at 105 pounds and while it took 70 seconds at first to drop the 15 pounds of pressure, after one hour of operation the internal was fairly steady at about 32 seconds. Pumping tests on the 2" line later showed no suction and so the 1" line had to be again utilized.

The water supply with this 1" intake is being taken from within 100 feet of the outlet from the septic tank that receives the sewage from the school. The septic tank does not discharge into the disposal bed but flows freely from tank to the lake so that there is no septic action in the tank whatsoever. The Principal of the School stated that the situation had been reported to the Indian Affairs Branch Medical Officer at Fort Frances and that he (that is the Principal) had instructed the Sister in charge at the school to boil all water for cooking and drinking. The Indian Agent was absent on treaty payments, the Medical Officer was away visiting the reserves and Inspector Hamilton of Winnipeg is also away until July, but it is expected that the Indian Agent and Medical Officer would be back in their offices over the past week-end and could assume responsibility for the dangerous situation that exists in connection with the present supply. A very simple solution would be to close the Institution now rather than wait until the holiday period commenced on July 1st.
Ottawa, June 22nd, 1946.

Re: Water Supply - Fort Frances Indian Residential School, Fort Frances, Ontario

Referring to Indian Affairs memorandum of April 2nd and further to ours of June 6th, we are now in receipt of a report from Mr. Gow dated June 17th, duplicate copies of which are attached.

The intake of the school water system appears to have become plugged and water is now pumped through a short length of temporary pipe which draws the water from the lake at a point within 100 feet of the outlet from the school septic tank.

As the water supplied to the school through this temporary intake might thus be contaminated, Mr. Gow suggests that the school be closed at once rather than continue it in operation until the end of this month when the usual summer holidays begin.

A report on the proposal to connect up the school with the Fort Frances town supply is expected shortly from Mr. Gow, who advises that owing to inability to obtain the necessary pipe the municipality will be unable to give the school a connection to their system before 1947 at the earliest.

We are writing Mr. Gow to ask him what arrangements can be made with a view to the restoration of the water supply.

WELFARE AND TRAINING.

Material has been ordered by the purchasing agent for the construction of a Farm Instructor's Residence at the Fort Frances Indian Residential School. Also, a new stoker has been installed at the School.
