In addition, of course, the school would have to pay 10¢ or 12¢ per thousand gallons for water actually used. If the school uses 8,000 gallons per day, which is a large amount, the annual cost would be $300 to $400 per year. This would be offset by Indian Affairs Branch being relieved by the town of any pumping or maintenance costs.

On the whole the proposal that a 6-in. main be laid to the school at a cost of $6,000.00 to Indian Affairs Branch, with a water rate of 10¢ or 12¢ per thousand gallons, and the town to be responsible for maintenance, seems to us reasonable. If, after reconsideration, you concur in this view, we would be agreeable to sending Mr. Gow instructions to negotiate as favourable an agreement with the town as possible, but if necessary he could tentatively agree to the foregoing terms.

In this connection we would refer you to correspondence in 1942 and 1943 regarding the water supply to Coqualeetza Hospital at Bardis, B.C. In that case, after very lengthy consideration, we recommended that Indian Affairs Branch contribute $4200 towards the installation by the Elk Creek Water Company of a 10-in. water main, two and one-half miles in length, and which main would provide service to many other customers of the Company. This $4200 was approximately one-third of the total cost of the proposed new main. In addition, we recommended that a new 6-in. main, 1600 feet in length, be installed from the 10-in. main to the hospital, at a cost of $1,575, and the installation of a fire pump at $1,650, these costs to be borne solely by Indian Affairs. It is seemingly impossible to locate the intake or for that matter any portion of the line beyond the water's edge. With very calm conditions it might be possible to observe some air leakages from the pipe line with the Town's air compressor in operation and I am suggesting to Mr. Lockhart that this again be attempted whenever a favourable condition exists. The leakage under 100 lb. pressure was small so that detection of the air bubbles along 1800 feet of unlocated pipe line requires perfect conditions which do not prevail only infrequently. There is now no diver obtainable from either Kenora or Fort Frances but if the pipe line can be located it would probably be possible to secure the services of a diver from Port Arthur or Fort William to attach a new intake screen.

If the present line cannot be located so as to make it again usable, it would appear necessary to lay a new 2" line from the shore line connection extending into the lake at least 400 feet. There would be danger from contaminated water at even this distance but probably less danger than if the water supply were taken from shallow well constructed near the shore line anywhere within 500 or 400 feet of the school building. We have no profile of the lake bottom out from the present shore line but the difficulty in connection with this new line would be in getting sufficient protection against freezing throughout the first 50 feet of this line. The present water level is about 496.5 and it is possible that this lake will be drawn down to elevation 494 by next spring. We will endeavour to secure from some reputable firm in Fort Frances a quotation covering the cost of pipe, the laying of the pipe and the protection for the same. The 2" suction pipe extends underground from the pump house to the shore line of Rainy Lake - a distance of about 300 feet; being about 6 feet underground at the shore line. There is a check valve in the line at the shore line and this was exposed by excavation at the time of the original failure of the water supply. Immediately beyond the check valve the 2" line dips steeply down under the lake bed for a total length of 1800 feet from the pump house. There is no obstruction between the pump and the check valve at the shore line inasmuch as the 1" temporary line is connected at the shore line and is now serving the water supply for the school, barns and etc. Of the line beyond the shore line probably nothing is known regarding location or condition. It was my intention to utilise a motor boat or rowboat with a drag line of some kind to locate the pipe line out from the shore. Dear Mr. Leechart:

The writer recently met with the Council of the Town of Fort Frances and found them quite agreeable to arranging to cooperate with the Indian Affairs Branch for the extension of the town water supply to the Indian Residential Schools. It is hoped that the 6" pipe will be available in 1947 to enable this work to be carried out. In the meantime it is necessary to take steps to ensure an adequate water supply to the Indian School until such time as the town supply is available. As you are aware, the present water supply intake is plugged up as a temporary expedient; the school have laid a short length of 1" pipe connecting with the old line at the shore line and are utilizing water which cannot help but be contaminated.

We appreciate the fact that the present pipe line has been in place for a long time, that it must be in poor condition and also difficult to locate. However, before abandoning this pipe line entirely and laying a shorter line, we believe another attempt should be made to locate the old line. As you are aware, we have had the town air compressor with crew attempt to clear the line without success. The lake was too rough and unsettled to permit any attempts being made to detect any air leaks along the suspected location of intake pipe. We believe a further attempt should be made with the compressor, not to clear the line, but to force air into the line so as to observe any air leaks that may occur and thus locate and mark the position of the pipe so that later it can be broken and a new intake screen attached. The test can only be successful when very calm conditions will prevent any air bubbles being observed from a boat and should not be attempted otherwise. We are unable to spare an engineer to proceed to Fort Frances and await such a favourable condition. It would be greatly appreciated if you could contact Mr. Henry, Town Engineer, and the School Engineer and arrange for such a test being made when calm conditions do prevail. The school has a suitable boat for observing the results of the test. If the pipe line can be located and marked with a small buoy or float, we can see about obtaining the services of a diver from Port Arthur to trace the pipe and affix a screw at some safe distance from the shore line.

If this test, made under favourable conditions, shows negative results then it will be necessary to lay a new 6" pipe line from the shore line check valve location out about 400 feet into the lake. This line will have to be laid so as to be safe from freezing conditions in winter and also with an anticipated lowering of Rainy Lake by two feet below its present level. We would also appreciate it if you would contact Mr. Smith, Contractor, formerly the John East Estate, and secure from him as close an estimate as he can give of the cost of 400 feet of 6" pipe, the expense involved in laying and connecting such a pipe line and also the cost of covering such line in the vicinity of the shore line so as to ensure it will prove free from frost action for the ensuing winter. It is realized that any such estimate as may be given by Mr. Smith can only be approximate. It will, however, serve our purpose for requesting a suitable amount of money.

Yours very truly,

D.B.Cow, District Chief Engineer.

I would strongly recommend that the Indian Affairs Branch advance Mr. Lockhart, Indian Agent at Fort Frances, Six Hundred dollars ($600.00) and authorize him to engage Mr. August Kivinski to lay the 400 foot intake out into the lake from the shore line and make the necessary changes in the pump room. The work involved is as follows:

Clear right-of-way pipe line by removal of rock rip-rap; providing 400 feet of 2" pipe, black or galvanized, if available, or steel if the other makes are not available, together with all necessary foot valves, check valves, relief valves, screen and etc. The connection of this new line with the existing intake at the present check valve on the shore line and the extension of the line 400 feet into the lake. Backfilling of all excavation and protection of pipe as far as possible out to a depth of 4 feet of water. The installation of a drain pipe from the pressure tank to the existing drain and placing of check valve and relief valve on this line so as to permit of continuous operation of the pump.

Admittedly there is some element of danger in depending upon such a source of water supply for the following two reasons:

(1) There is danger of an interruption to the electric power - a danger which may be considered as rather remote and less likely to happen than a break-down of the small pumping plant.

(2) There is a danger of contaminated water after ice forms insomuch as the intake will be only about 500 feet removed from the present outlet from the scum-tic tank. To overcome this last danger, it will be essential that the Medical Health Officer for the Indian Affairs Branch at Fort Frances secure frequent samples of water in use and have same tested. (See page 5.)
The writer has just returned from Fort Frances where the matter of the above mentioned project was discussed with local plumbing firms, the Town's Works Superintendent, the Principal of the School and Indian Agent Lockhart.

It appears hopeless to attempt to locate and utilize the existing intake placed some 41 years ago and so a new shorter intake is now necessary. It is proposed to lay 400 feet of 2" pipe from the shore line out into the lake and connect same to the existing line at the point where it dips at a 45° slope under the lake bed and the location of the check valve. Some years ago, to protect the foreshore from erosion, broken stone rip-rap was dumped along the bank in considerable quantity. This rip-rap is composed of large pieces of broken stone extending from above the present water line to about 25 feet into the lake where there is a present depth of 5 feet of water. The present lake level is very high, being only 0.5 feet below the maximum summer regulated limit. This rock must be removed sufficiently to permit of the laying of a new line along the lake bottom and its removal will involve considerable effort and expense as it is entirely under water. Mainly Lake will undoubtedly be drawn down over two feet during the coming winter and ice will form to a depth of 6 feet so that it is going to be difficult to protect the intake from freezing through out the 100 feet length extending from the connection to the old intake. The proper method of protection would involve construction of heavy timber cribwork with boarded sides and earth fill. The exposed shore line and heavy ice shove would necessitate very heavy protection.

There is interest in a water supply for one year only and proposes to eliminate such type of protection. The 2" pipe line will be laid along the lake bottom and will be covered with earth, sand, gravel and rock until a depth of 4 feet of water is reached. To prevent the intake freezing, it is proposed to operate the pump in the pump house continuously. This will be accomplished by connecting one of the pressure tanks to the existing drain in the pump house and inserting a relief valve to open at 60% pressure or just below the pressure at which the pump now cuts out. The present pump is operated by a 1/3 h.p. motor and when the school is in operation this pump is going almost continuously during the day. Provided no break-down occurs in connection with this pump, it is considered that continuous flow of water from the intake will prevent freezing. There is also a large pump in the pump room which is also used for pumping water and in case of emergency this can be utilized to continue the continuous pumping.

The labour and material situation at Fort Frances at the present time is very difficult. I was unable to locate any supply of 2" black or galvanized pipe and from inquiries made, I am confident that none will be available in time for this job. Dear Sir:

I have recourse to you, to help me solve the difficulties I encountered with the putting up of a new house here at the Indian School.

First it was decided that the house would be for the farmer instructor, but the building we now occupy is more like a home for a family. So, it was agreed with Rev. Father Provincial and consent from the Indian Agent that we would build the new house for the Fathers, thus satisfying the farmer, the Fathers and school's staff. It will give more space to the farmer, more rooms for classrooms; children are really too crowded. The Principal will take his quarters in the new building instead of at school.

It was agreed that the Department would pay for the material used and the Principal would pay labor.

There came a shortage; I had to buy more lumber etc. Actually I have in hand a bill of $1,220.22 not paid. I enclose the list of the items.

I already paid $1,322.43 of salary to the workers.

In view of all this, I beg the Department to help me. At least, in my opinion, all material should be paid by the Department. So, will the Department prefer to pay directly the different Companies or give me the authority to do so with the assurance of reimbursement?

May I have a prompt answer, Sir, to this letter.

I have the hope that you will be able to settle this matter advantageously to all concern.

Thanking you in advance, I remain, Sir,

Yours very truly,

P. Chatelain, O.M.I.,
Principal.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Water Supply
Fort Frances Indian Residential School

Referring to your notation on a copy of a memorandum of July 23, 1946 from Indian Affairs in connection with the above water supply, we are now in receipt of further information from Mr. Gow under date of February 11th:

"Following the forwarding of our letter of June 20th last, the water supply situation at the Indian School became quite serious. The intake line into the lake became plugged; we were unable to clear the same and later efforts to locate the line were futile. It was necessary to lay a short line of 400 feet out into the lake in order to secure an emergency water supply for the winter months. This emergency water supply line was laid at a total cost for labor and material of $374.42. We are hopeful that this temporary line will not fail because of freezing before next spring. However, the outer end of this short intake is only 500 feet from the sewer outlet and the present intake can only be considered an emergency measure until some other safe water supply is available.

There are the two alternatives for a water supply for this school, namely, the laying of a new 4" intake out into the lake or an agreement with the Town of Fort Frances for extension of their water supply to the school. The laying of a new intake with the necessary protective criteria against freezing and etc., would probably entail an initial expenditure greater than the proposed payment to the Town of Fort Frances. The water supply would be contaminated and also would provide no appreciable measure of fire protection. The advantages of reaching an agreement with the Town are so apparent that the building of a new intake could not possibly be justified and apparently the officials of the Town of Fort Frances are quite aware of this situation. Our negotiations with the Town of Fort Frances with respect to the proposed extension of their water supply to the Indian School were as outlined in our letter of June 20th last and since that date we have had no further contact with them with respect to the proposal. However, we forwarded to you, under date of July 30th, a copy of a letter from Mr. Lockhart, Indian Agent at Fort Frances, in which he stated that the property owners held a meeting a few days previous with the Town officials and agreed to pay $3,000.00 in cash towards laying of the water main to the school over their respective lots. The latter also advised that the Town of Fort Frances had placed an order for sufficient pipe and expected delivery early in 1947. Mr. Lockhart now advises, under date of February 5th, that Mayor B.V.Holmes, Fort Frances, had informed him that they had received the necessary pipe."

February 5, 1947.

Mr. J. E. Doucet,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Reverend Father Lavigne visited our school recently. He asked me to expose the situation of our former pupils and to ask your help in order to improve the present conditions.

Our Coutchiching Reserve, where our school is located, has a population of almost 400 members. All are Christians and Catholics. There are three cases of concubinage. The parents are fairly true to the practices of their religion. For a number of years, our youth go to Fort Frances and to International Falls where they enjoy themselves. There are theatres, pool-rooms, restaurants, and ill-kept houses, where they particularly find liquor, and several of our young people have been in jail for a certain time.

This is a deplorable situation which the parents admit themselves.

This is why they have requested the following in their brief: "Considering that our reserve is situated near a town and a border town (International Falls, Minn.) and that, due to this fact our boys and girls led astray, it is the opinion of the members that the Department should erect a recreation hall on our reserve, equipped with modern amusements so that it may help to keep our children home."

I know that this is impossible at the present time. However could we not get a talking picture machine which we could use with profit in our parochial hall, and other articles such as musical instruments, boxing gloves, foot-balls, base-ball and soft ball equipment, etc.

Hoping that it will be possible for you to help us, we remain,

P. Chatelain, O.M.I.

Ottawa, March 11th, 1947.

Mr. J.F. Lockhart, Indian Agent,
Fort Frances, Ontario.

We enclose for your information copy of letter received from the Reverend Principal of the Fort Frances Residential School urging the erection of a recreation hall on the Couchiching Reserve.

We regret that we have no funds provided in our appropriation that could be used for the erection of this building. However, it is possible that the Council might be willing to vote the money required from their Band Funds.

If the Band is willing to provide the expenditure required, the following points should be taken into consideration:

1. The Indian Council should decide on the plan of the building and obtain an estimate of its approximate cost.

2. The Council should pass the necessary resolution requesting expenditure from Band funds.

3. The resolution passed by the Band, together with the plan of the proposed building and an estimate of the cost should be submitted to this office in order that we may forward it to the Minister with a view to obtaining his approval.

If Reverend Father Chatelain has not already discussed the matter with you, I suggest that you interview him at an early date and obtain his views regarding what is required before submitting the whole matter to the Couchiching Band.

Bernard F. Keary

Dear Mr. Cow:

Re: Water Line - Idlewyld to Industrial School

At a meeting held on September 12, 1946, the land owners of Idlewyld committed themselves to a portion of the expense to the Town of Fort Frances for the installation of a water line through or past their property. These signatures were procured for the committee by Mr. R. McTaggart and Mr. G.C. Baeker of Port Frances.

At an interview with the Town Clerk, Mr. J.W. Walker, our committee was informed that the Town had not received any approving commitments from the Department of Industrial Schools. It is necessary to have these commitments before the Town Council will pass on the installation of the water main.

I am writing you at this time to press upon you the importance of immediate action as this installation depends on the co-operative approval of the Town of Fort Frances, the Department representing Industrial Schools, and the property owners of the Idlewyld Division. Already the Town of Fort Frances have signified their cooperation.

To give you further information regarding the property owners, a majority of them only require summer service; therefore if it is necessary, this coming summer, for them to install individual water systems, it will possibly discourage a number of supporting the installation of this proposed water line future date.

Furthermore, our committee have been informed that the pipe the Town last fall is on hand ready for use in the installation of the contemplated water main.

Therefore, it would be greatly appreciated if you would give your immediate attention.

Yours very truly,

President "B.V. Green"

PROPERTY OWNERS, IDLEWYLD SUB-
Mr. Lee

Will you kindly advise of your wishes in regard to this matter.

Ottawa, March 14, 1947

Memorandum

Re: Water Supply - Fort Frances Indian Residential School, Fort Frances, Ont.

Referring to our memorandum of February 13th on the subject of an agreement with the Town of Fort Frances towards the provision of a water supply for the school from the town system, we have not yet received any reply.

Mr. Gow writes again under date of March 12th as follows:

"We wrote you under date of February 11th in connection with the above mentioned subject but to date have received no advice as to any action having resulted. We are now enclosing copy of a letter received from the President of the Property Owners, Idlewyld Subdivision at Fort Frances, with further reference to this subject.

The Town Engineer of Fort Frances has the water pipe on hand and planned to proceed with the excavation for and the laying of the pipe line while the ground was frozen and thus eliminated a great deal of expense by eliminating the necessity for shoring the deep excavation. It was planned to do the work by excavating machinery. The delay of the Indian Affairs Branch in making known their desires with respect to an agreement, is therefore unfortunate. All that is required from the Indian Affairs Branch to permit this work to proceed immediately is a commitment that it will contribute $500.00 towards the project. The details of the Agreement can be arranged later along the lines as tentatively arranged by the writer with the town's officials.

I am informed that the Indian Affairs Branch are including an item in the 1947-48 Estimates to cover this grant. However, I believe $7,000.00 was voted in the 1946-47 Estimates for "Fort Frances Water Supply and Heating Repairs". The heating repairs were carried out and new stoker installed so that presumably the item was voted at least $6,000.00 should remain for this project to be paid for from the present fiscal year's funds. I would urge that the Indian Affairs Branch be asked to take immediate action with respect to the water supply, otherwise they may be faced with the necessity of installing a pipe line out into the lake during the coming summer."

You will note the desire of the Town Engineer to proceed with the installation of the new pipeline during the winter months. There are of course objections which might be advanced to the adoption of the idea of installing such a pipeline during severe winter weather. However it would be a decided advantage to have the work proceed as soon as possible in the spring and to this end the agreement should be drawn up now and if the Town should

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.
Demand a payment from the Department before work is commenced; it might be possible to arrange this payment from current funds.

Memorandum

Re: Fort Frances Indian Residential School

Dear Sir:

The Superintendent of the Industrial School was in to see me two or three times in regard to the water charges which will be made against the school after the installation of water service. This is rather difficult to decide definitely at the present time.

Considering that circumstances are altogether different from any established rate, I have no precedent to go by. The local schools are open for only ten months of the year and are not occupied as residences, while this one is occupied as a residence the year round by practically about 110 persons.

In addition to this there is the consideration of farm service for which the water will be used, cattle etc. However, it may be that we shall put in a meter and under these circumstances, I think I can promise that the charge will not be over $1 per 1,000 gallons.

I would appreciate being informed if this would be acceptable to your Department.

Yours respectfully,

"J. W. Walker"
Clerk.

J.M.C
I am enclosing copy of a letter received from the Town of Fort Frances relating to the water supply for the Indian Residential School near Fort Frances. You will also find attached a reference to the minutes of the Council meeting on the water shortage and also the Town's recommendation to the effect that the charge for metered water will be raised eleven cents per thousand gallons.

Following the receipt of your letter of April 3rd, relating to the arrangements to be made with the Town of Fort Frances for a water supply, we wrote the Mayor of Fort Frances under date of April 5th, paragraphs of which read as follows:

"Will you please confer with your officials and have them draft a proposal in concert with the Indian Affairs Branch outlining the extent of the service to be rendered by the Town and the proposed financial terms covering initial cost and water rates to be charged. This draft a report should be sent here and if in line with the tentative arrangement previously discussed with our officials by the writer, then final action can be taken at an early date by the proper officials."

We have had no reply to this letter and inasmuch as the writer expects to be in Fort Frances shortly I am writing with these matters, we will call at the Town Office and endeavour to hurry up the proceedings.

Personally, I think a charge of $1.25 per 1,000 gallons is a very reasonable rate of compensation. The total annual costs to the Town are, or would be, $7,400. If the rate of $1.25 per 1,000 gallons, the annual net result to the Town would be $20,000—a very limited amount to provide for maintenance, inspection, and replacement of pipe, meter, hydrants, etc.

It is quite important that the School Board should be made responsible for the payment of the charges mentioned above. It is not intended to utilize the facilities of the school during the non-winter months. Such auxiliary pumping equipment is available and can be utilized by the school board.

I would ask that you advise this office at your earliest convenience whether or not assurance can be given to the Town of Fort Frances that a charge of not more than $1.25 cents initially for the one thousand gallons of water is reasonable.

(Signed) D. B. Cow

Further to our memorandum of May 8th we are now in receipt of the following letter from Mr. Gow dated May 27th in regard to the above subject:

"The writer was in Fort Frances on May 23rd and discussed with the Town Engineer and the Town Clerk the present situation with respect to the proposed extension of the town water supply to the Indian Residential School.

"The 6" pipe required for the project has now been on hand for some time and work will commence as soon as some other important work is completed, probably within three or four weeks. Due to increased cost of pipe, valves, hydrants and labour, the estimated cost of the line is now $17,495.00. Of this, the proportion to be paid by the Indian Affairs Branch remains at $5,000. The 6" main will be laid from the main supply near the pumping tank to the vicinity of the barn at the school and a 3" line will branch off to feed the school. Understand there are two stand pipes in the school and it is proposed that the feed line to the school should be sufficient to feed both these in case of fire. Two hydrants will be installed, one in the vicinity of the barns and one at the school but all alterations within the school and connections beyond the main and 3" lines will be the responsibility of the Indian Affairs Branch. The charge for water will not exceed eleven cents per thousand gallons metered, but the Town Engineer is reluctant to install a meter which will cost $800.00, so that the charge for water may be based on a flat yearly rate. Personally, I favour the metering of the water since this will reduce the amount of water used and the agreement most assuredly will contain a clause which prohibits the use of water from the hydrants for any purpose except for extinguishing fires. At the present time the sewage disposal plant at the school is inoperative and the sewage is passing directly through the septic tank into Rainy Lake. Eventually, we are going to be required to dispose of this sewage by some other method and the amount of effluent becomes important.

A short time ago a new electric range was supplied to the above school and they have had considerable trouble as it was necessary to change fuses every two hours and only able to get four burners to work. The Principal called in Mr. Robert Taylor, Superintendent of Public Utilities for the Town of Fort Frances, who accompanied with an Inspector of the Ontario Hydro Electric Commission visited the school and found that the load being carried by the school is in excess to the present system.

From what I can ascertain the present line was put in in 1922 and was ample for the school's requirements then, however, a stoker and other motors have since been installed until the line is over-loaded.

Further to our memorandum of September 9th, in which we advised you that we were taking up with Mr. Gow the matter of fire protection and whether an additional clause should be placed in the agreement, we have now received the following letter from Mr. Gow:

"This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of September 10 with reference to the above mentioned subject and ask for certain information with respect to the installation which has been made by the Town of Fort Frances at the school.

With respect to a clause regarding fire protection, it was the intention that the Town of Fort Frances would be responsible for providing fire protection to the Indian Residential School without any charge, even though the Institution is located outside of the Municipal area. Inasmuch as the 6" hydrant is between the meter and the town water supply, there would be no charge for water as there would be no way of measuring the same. The writer has not inspected the installation but the arrangements completed were that there would be one hydrant only. Originally it was agreed that the town would provide two hydrants, one in the vicinity of the school and one in the vicinity of the barn. However, upon the occasion of my last visit to the site, it was agreed that one hydrant would be sufficient, if conveniently placed so as to serve any one or all of the building structures.

As previously pointed out, I will eventually prepare a plan of the school grounds showing the location of the water line and the different connections to buildings on the school property. We will also be writing you particularly with respect to the dismantling of the pumps, pressure tanks and intake piping."

You will note from the above, that the water provided by the Town of Fort Frances in the event of a fire at the school will not pass through the meter; therefore, it would be advisable to place a clause in the agreement to the effect that water will be supplied by the Town for the purpose of fire protection through a hydrant installed free of cost.

WHEREAS the Corporation of the Town of Port Francis, by virtue of an agreement with the Corporation of the Township of MacIrvine, has installed a water main to the Indian Residential School situated on the shore of Sand Bay, Rainy Lake, near the said town and in the said township;

AND WHEREAS the said installation is for the purpose of supplying water to the said Indian Residential School; His Majesty has agreed to pay to the said Corporation of the Town of Port Francis the sum of Six Thousand Dollars ($6000.00) therefore,

NOW, THEREFORE, THIS AGREEMENT WITNESSETH that the parties hereto agree, each with the other, as follows:

2. 3. That the Corporation of the Town of Port Francis shall supply, free of charge, at all times, its full fire fighting equipment and personnel to fight and extinguish any fires which may occur at any time in or to the said Indian Residential School.
